utterances: So here's my question.
I'll start with you, Laura.
Is that a difference the American public can accept?
I - well that remains to be seen.
I think it's a very appealing argument.
Basically, they're saying we were wrong three years ago, but we're right now to stay in this.
And they keep connecting anything that happens as a provocation against us as connected to September 11th.

So you better believe next Monday they're going to be out there front and center using that September 11th Fifth Anniversary to connect to everything that's going on in Iran, and everything that's going on in Lebanon, and everything that's going on in Iraq.
And they're going to say we cannot afford to abandon the Middle East.
And by walking out of Iraq, that's what we're doing.
And I think that's going to appeal to some folks who are really jittery about national security.
Hey, Tony, I'll connect it right now.
Go ahead.
There are more people who - there are more U.S.
soldiers who have died in Iraq than the people who died in the World Trade Center attacks.
That is a reality.
And if we, when you have a position to say, at first, we have to win.
Now it's we have to lose, then you're going to see the linkage between Vietnam.
When we begin to say, oh no, we can't pull out.
It's going to hurt the - hurt, you know, in terms of the standing of America in the rest of the world.
It's already been hurt and shattered.
We have not created a better situation.
We have not.
And at some point, the administration, they probably won't get it.
But the American people day by day are understanding that, and that is what is hurting the president the most.
No, I…
Well, Michael Meyers, is that distinction without a - a difference without a distinction now?
I think its naïve.
I don't think Americans even - most Americans, many Americans, I'll modify it that way - even know where Iraq or Iran is on a map.
And…
Well, they know their sons and daughters are dying.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I, you know, I think a lot of people feel the world is falling apart.
Not just Iran, not just Iraq, but, you know, North Korea, the Middle East, natural disasters, age-old religious ethnic national conflicts, homelessness, disease, Africa, poverty, slavery.
People feel that the world is falling apart, and therefore they're looking for religion or they're not looking for religion as an answer.
And it goes back home.
It comes back to the domestic issues.
Because Bush and his crowd are saying, look, the world is falling apart.
The world is perilous.
Who will you trust to keep us safe?
Who will you trust to keep us against - to hold the line against terrorism?
And that's where it comes back to the domestic issues, because they're going to use the word liberal again.
Do you trust the liberals, who are mostly concerned about quote/unquote civil liberties as opposed to people who want people checked, profiled in any possible when they get on an airplane?
People - American voters vote based on their fears and their passions and their prejudices.
All right, well let's...
And they're telling, they're telling…
And the Bush administration again must know that.
Let's, ah…
Tony Lib is not playing!
Well, that's true.
Tony Lib, Tony Liberal is not going to play.
The reason the polls are changing right now is because the Democrats haven't even said or done anything.
People have a backlash against the administration and their policies.
Just imagine if the Democrats had a basic plan to change America.
You think it's not going to play in Connecticut?
You think Joe Lieberman is going down - who's riding the coattails of George W.
Bush's Middle East policies.
Do you think he is going down?
Do you think that the Republicans are not going to run against liberal Howard Dean and say they can beat Howard Dean at the polls?
Come on!
This is not 2004, Michael.
They may say that - yeah, that's absolutely - let me, we have about three minutes left, and I want to hit one other topic before we get away.
And try to, if you can - I know you guys all have wonderful things to say, but try to stay on point as much as you can.
Kofi Annan has been a very busy man.
His Middle East mission to Iran, Syria, Israel, Lebanon - he's been all over the place.
Basically, how effective was this trip for him and the United Nations as a whole?
Do you get the sense that he made a difference at all, Laura?
No, I don't.
Yeah.
I think he had to go and he had to put - basically, he's putting his personal credibility on the line on this.
But we really haven't made a lot of movement.
And so I think that he, at this point now, he's going to have sit on the sidelines.
What do you say, Roland?
Unidentified Man #1: Check out the blue.
And there's your pink, or is that more of a magenta, I don't know anymore.
I would disagree in that, first of all, for him to even get the Israelis as well as Hezbollah to agree to mediation is significant.
You're talking about folks who have a no-talk policy, who refuse to even communicate with one another because they set up very hard standards.
And so just to even get them to talking to one another I think is a big step, because that's huge.
They don't talk.
Has there really been, though, in your view Michael Meyers, significant movement?
There's been a lot of talking, and Roland Martin is correct about that.
But action is one of the issues that people are looking for.
You've got about a minute or so.
What do you say?
Well, I think Kofi Annan, it's time for him to go.
Really?
You know, I think he's been inept.
I don't think he's been effective.
I don't think he's respected.
I agree with Laura in that regard.
I see mostly this shuttling diplomacy a little late - very late.
I mean, are the prisoners yet released, or is that Jesse Jackson's job?
You know…
Well, if it's Jesse Jackson's job, he hasn't done a very good job with that either.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's true.
Yeah, yeah, nobody.
Nobody is a very good diplomat anymore.
Yeah.
Yeah.
The world is falling apart, and the U.N.
is - I mean the deadline has passed.
(Unintelligible), I can't tell you what these people are doing in terms of, show me this or show me that.
But, these people…
Mike, could it be we have good diplomats but hard insights?
These folks are just incompetent.
Well, our time has run out, folks.
They can't even, they don't know how to talk!
We can't, we've got to stop right there.
In our Chicago bureau, Roland Martin, executive director - executive editor, excuse me, of The Chicago Defender.
Laura Washington, Chicago Sun-Times columnist.
Michael Meyers, executive director of the New York Civil Rights Coalition.
My last question, you can answer it in unity.
This is a one-word answer, yes or no: are you going to watch Katie Couric tonight?
Are you kidding?
(Soundbite of laughter)
I'll take that as a no.
